bestBHT.bht: The commandment given by the chief priests and Pharisees had led to questioning and conjectures about whether Jesus would appear at the feast. The purpose clause emphasizes their determination to seize him, which is mentioned to account for these speculations. These verses reveal the preparations made by both Jesus' friends and foes for what was to come. Some individuals actively sought to find and expose Jesus to the chief priests and Pharisees, motivated by the promised reward.

Henry Alford: The former is in my view most probable; for the command having been given would satisfactorily account for the questioning, and not be stated merely as co-ordinate with it.
Without it, the verse is merely an explanation of the people’s question, which was asked in consequence of the order having been issued by the chief priests&c.
With it, it would mean, ‘And besides, the chief priests’&c.; i.e. ‘not only did the people question, but’&c.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Chief priests and the Pharisees had given a commandment... they might take him."
This is mentioned to account for the conjectures...
Conjectures whether He would come, in spite of this determination to seize Him.
Philip Schaff: In pursuance of the resolve related above (John 11:53) commandments had been issued... that all the faithful should aid in apprehending Jesus." (17 words)
These latter verses show us the friends and foes of Jesus alike occupying the field in preparation for the end." (21 words)
Archibald T. Robertson: The chief priests and the Pharisees... had given commandment... that he should show it."
If any man knew where he was... that they might take him."
Purpose clause with οπως instead of ινα... so often used before.
John Gill: Now both the chief priests and the Pharisees... had given a commandment... that if any man knew where he were, he should show [it], that they might take him."
This made it a doubtful point with some, whether he would come to the feast or not."
Others sought for him, and inquired after him, that they might discover him to the chief priests and Pharisees, and have the promised reward.

bhtAttempts.bht: The chief priests and the Pharisees had given a commandment to apprehend Jesus, which led to people questioning whether Jesus would come to the feast. The purpose clause in the verse emphasizes the determination to seize Jesus, and the commandment was mentioned to explain the conjectures that arose as a result. These verses show how both the friends and foes of Jesus were making preparations for the end, with some seeking to discover his whereabouts for the promised reward.

The commandment given by the chief priests and Pharisees to apprehend Jesus led to speculation about his potential attendance at the feast. The purpose clause, mentioned in the commentary, highlights their determination to seize him. This verse illustrates the preparations made by both friends and foes of Jesus in anticipation of what was to come. Some sought after Jesus to discover his location, hoping to receive the promised reward for revealing it.

The commandment issued by the chief priests and Pharisees to apprehend Jesus gave rise to speculation regarding his potential presence at the feast. The purpose clause underscores their determination to seize him. These verses shed light on the preparations made by both the friends and foes of Jesus in anticipation of what was to unfold. Some individuals actively sought Jesus and made inquiries to reveal his location, hoping to receive the promised reward for their actions.

The commandment given by the chief priests and Pharisees had led to questioning and conjectures about whether Jesus would appear at the feast. The purpose clause emphasizes their determination to seize him, which is mentioned to account for these speculations. These verses reveal the preparations made by both Jesus' friends and foes for what was to come. Some individuals actively sought to find and expose Jesus to the chief priests and Pharisees, motivated by the promised reward.

The chief priests and Pharisees had issued a commandment to capture Jesus, which resulted in people questioning whether he would attend the feast. The purpose clause reflects their strong determination to seize him, an explanation given for the various conjectures. These verses illustrate the preparations made by both Jesus' friends and enemies in anticipation of the impending end. Some individuals searched for Jesus and inquired about his whereabouts, intending to reveal him to the chief priests and Pharisees in hopes of obtaining the promised reward.
